text: I love the maidens for unreal, because they go away, because they don't like to obey, because they embody the last vestiges of free labor and voluntary hiring and they have no insurance or benefits; because as ghosts of an extinct race come, they break into houses, husk, dig, resemble the abyss of our secret petty servants reading in the remains of coffee cups or cups of goat's-meal, in the collars, or simply introducing their sneaky looks and their greedy hands into the closets, under the pillows, or picking up the pieces of our broken little hands and the echo of our broken hearts, while their cremated cream and barrel of our little malfias and the vines of our little vengeful wine are finally being left in the canteen; they now seem to be clinging to the last of his kind, and they are now, because they are now, and they are not, and they are not, now, and they are not, because they are not, and they are not, yet, and they are not yet, and they are not yet, and they are not yet, because they are not yet, and they are not yet, and they are not yet, and they are not yet, and they are not yet, and they are, and they are not yet, and they are, because they are now, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and they are, and I'm leaving, they tell him vigorously filling his cardboard boxes once again. But why? Because yes (oh, ineffable freedom!) And there they go, evil angels, looking for new adventures, a new home, a new cat, a new washing machine, a new lady who can't live without them and loves them; planning a new life, denying gratitude for the good treatment they received when they got sick and lovingly giving them their aspirin for fear that the next day they won't be able to wash the dishes, which is what really tires, making the food doesn't tire. I love to see them come, call, smile, enter, say yes; but no, always resisting to find their Mary Poppins-Lady who solves all their problems, those of their fathers, those of their younger and older brothers, among whom one raped them at his opportunity; who at night teaches them in bed to sing do-re-mi, do-re-mi until they fall asleep with the thought put sweetly on the morning dishes submerged in a new wave of foam of fab-sol-la-si detergent, and gently caresses their hair and turns away without making noise, of dots, and turns off the light at the last moment before leaving the room of vaguely irradiated contours. FIN
title: Las criadas
author: Augusto Monterroso
